description: David Hume's empiricist skepticism establishing the psychological foundations of knowledge and the limits of human understanding
author: Bryan A. Spruk

entries.definition: We never perceive a necessary connection between cause and effect â€” only constant conjunction observed through experience.
examples: Seeing billiard balls collide doesn't reveal 'necessary connection'
Fire following flint strike is constant conjunction, not necessity

entries.definition: No logical basis guarantees the future will resemble the past; inductive belief rests on habit and custom, not rational necessity.
examples: Sun rising every day doesn't prove it will tomorrow
Inductive science rests on unjustified assumptions

entries.definition: Vivid, immediate, forceful perceptions arising from direct sensory experience or internal emotions.
Faint copies of impressions in thought, memory, and imagination. All ideas ultimately derive from impressions.
Primary drivers of belief and expectation. Through repetition, the mind forms habits that guide future expectations.
examples: Expecting bread to nourish after eating it repeatedly
Believing in gravity through constant observation

learning_principles: Be skeptical of claims beyond direct experience.
Understand that reasoning often rests on psychological patterns, not logic.
Recognize the limits of certainty in human knowledge.
All ideas derive from impressions through mental operations.
Causation is a psychological association, not a logical necessity.

impression_analysis.description: Analyze experience into impressions and ideas

causation_assessment.description: Evaluate causal claims for psychological vs logical basis

inductive_skepticism.description: Apply Hume's critique to inductive inferences
